page.name: Topic 1.1: Understanding pre-apprenticeships
page.content:
Overview

Apprenticeships expand career opportunities, but many adults face barriers to accessing them. Pre-apprenticeships break down these barriers by supporting adults to prepare for and succeed in apprenticeships and other industry roles. Pre-apprenticeship programs open up critical pathways into rewarding careers — driving greater and more diverse participation in apprenticeships and the broader workforce. These programs also benefit employers by providing screened, well-trained employees.

Pre-apprenticeship programs can be delivered full time or part time. Some are designed to mimic a typical workday, and others are scheduled to accommodate participants’ other commitments. These programs are typically taught in person, but some use blended or online models. Pre-apprenticeships often have partnerships with a range of industry employers, but a relationship with an apprenticeship program is what distinguishes them from other adult education or workforce readiness programs. 

Pre-apprenticeship programs offer career exposure, skill development, job readiness preparation, and holistic supports. High-quality pre-apprenticeships:

  • Set clear pathways into apprenticeships and other in-demand industry roles,
  • Articulate clear entry and success requirements,
  • Help participants acquire skills and credentials sought by employers and apprenticeship programs, and
  • Provide support services to remove barriers to participation, including access to resources for transportation, childcare, mental health, and housing.

Review the resources listed below to learn more about pre-apprenticeships.

 Recommended reading

  • What is a pre-apprenticeship program? (U.S. Department of Labor). The DOL website provides an introduction to pre-apprenticeships — including their benefits and the elements of high-quality programs. Read the case studies to learn more about what pre-apprenticeships can look like across industries and with different participants.
  • JFF’s framework for a high-quality pre-apprenticeship program (Jobs for the Future). This framework outlines six characteristics of high-quality pre-apprenticeships. It is designed to help new or existing programs to improve program quality and equity.
  • Principles for a high-quality pre-apprenticeship: a model to advance equity (The Center for Law and Social Policy). This report outlines principles for designing high-quality pre-apprenticeships. It identifies similar elements to the JFF Framework identified above but has a deeper focus on how to create equitable, inclusive programs.

Recommended viewing

  • The essentials of a high-quality pre-apprenticeship program — webinar recording  (Jobs for the Future). In addition to reading JFF’s framework above, you may also wish to watch this webinar featuring guest speakers from IBM and Pennsylvania’s Apprenticeship and Training Office.
